posts.text: Safety isn't a property of a knowledge-containing agent. It's a property of the environment in which that agent is deployed.

reply_context.text: Either the capability is there and the model is ignorant of the danger possible from its suggestions, or the model is aware of the dangers and can recognize from context when they are potentially at play. You can't pack it all in one model and have it both ways.

posts.text: Either the capability is there and the model is ignorant of the danger possible from its suggestions, or the model is aware of the dangers and can recognize from context when they are potentially at play. You can't pack it all in one model and have it both ways.

reply_context.text: Sure, it's harder to get a model to make meth if it's never heard of it, but if the model understands basic OChem and I show it the structure of a precursor and my intended synthesis target, the definition of "it understands chemistry" requires that it can propose feasible synthesis steps.

posts.text: Sure, it's harder to get a model to make meth if it's never heard of it, but if the model understands basic OChem and I show it the structure of a precursor and my intended synthesis target, the definition of "it understands chemistry" requires that it can propose feasible synthesis steps.

reply_context.text: Falling back on the chemistry example: if I want a model that won't make meth, I'm probably better served teaching it what meth is so it can recognize when the user is trying to reach that outcome.

posts.text: Falling back on the chemistry example: if I want a model that won't make meth, I'm probably better served teaching it what meth is so it can recognize when the user is trying to reach that outcome.

reply_context.text: If a domain of knowledge is unsafe, then there simply is no way you can train a model to be an expert in that domain which guarantees the knowledge won't be used for nefarious purposes. Either the model is nerfed in "dangerous" domains, or the model is capable of being used for "unsafe" purpose.

posts.text: If a domain of knowledge is unsafe, then there simply is no way you can train a model to be an expert in that domain which guarantees the knowledge won't be used for nefarious purposes. Either the model is nerfed in "dangerous" domains, or the model is capable of being used for "unsafe" purpose.

reply_context.text: If a model is "PhD level intelligent", then we should expect that the model will be capable of all of the same things that a kidnapped and tortured human with those credentials would be capable of. It's a fundamental conflict about what it means for something to have intelligence about a domain.

posts.text: If a model is "PhD level intelligent", then we should expect that the model will be capable of all of the same things that a kidnapped and tortured human with those credentials would be capable of. It's a fundamental conflict about what it means for something to have intelligence about a domain.

Part of why I don't think this is possible is because part of what it means to be safe in a chemistry lab is knowing that if you mix A with B it will explode and that's why you *don't*. 

Expert knowledge will always be abusable. I don't think it's possible to have it both ways.
